data.title: Task API feedback
data.body:
Just small things

* `TaskGroup` has a private ctor which is a little mean but I believe I understand why we have it that way. We have to make sure that we don't break anyone when we make it public, but I think its OK. 
* `ShellExecutionOptions` should be an `interface`, not just `type`
* In the provider function make the cancelation token optional like in other providers
* We need a better name for `TaskKind`... The `xyzKind`-naming scheme is already used by enums, like `TaskRevealKind`. Maybe `TaskData` because it is the serialisable portion of a task?

data.title: Set TERM_PROGRAM environment variable on integrated shell
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch VSCode from launcher and integrated shell.
2. `TERM_PROGRAM` is not set.
3. Launch VSCode within `iTerm2.app` by `code` command and open integrated shell. 
4. `TERM_PROGRAM` is set as `iTerm.app`

I change shell behavior by terminal applications. I set tmux to be launched only if `TERM_PROGRAM` equals `iTerm.app`. 

 VSCode does not set that environment variable however. `TERM_PROGRAM` is affected by applications launching VSCode.

Please set `TERMINAL_PROGRAM` variable like `vscode`, or add preference for environment variables on integrated shell :)

Related issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23295

data.title: Provide support for non standard CSS properties and features in VSCode
data.body:
Hi, I've been using VSCode a bunch for Dota 2 Custom Games, and it does the job great, except when it comes to how Valve have altered CSS to suit their needs.

A list of their properties can be found [here](https://developer.valvesoftware.com/wiki/Dota_2_Workshop_Tools/Panorama/CSS_Properties), and having the ability to enhance / replace the current CSS Schema with a new properties and restrictions, such as `hue-rotation` and hex based color inputs accepting 8 hexadecimal characters for color (`#333333b0`), as opposed to the normal 6 (`#FF0000`). 

With the colour input accepting 8 hexadecimal characters, this breaks the error handling in CSS
![Example](http://i.imgur.com/kpVc1ny.png)

Note I'm not asking to have Valves CSS properties being a part of VSCode, rather providing the infrastructure to allow users to enhance the existing language service with new properties or features.

(Posted this in Microsoft/vscode-css-languageservice#32 but doesn't appear active in that repository)

data.title: FontStyle not updating

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Discovered in #29393

The pull requests makes a change so that settings can specify color and fontStyle overrides for themes.

Updating colors works just fine, but if I add a setting for modifying the font style of a scope, the font style of those matching tokens won't actually re-render until I type to modify a token and then only that token is updated. See the gif below for an example.

**Note:** if I use the theme switcher to change to a new theme that has a font style applied for a scope.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2957173/27527129-546b01de-5a4a-11e7-9010-fadd636c14fa.png)

data.title: Support multiple TypeScript projects with shared library
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Win7

Steps to Reproduce:

Folder structure:
```
|- frontend
    |- typings
    |- tsconfig.json
|- backend
    |- typings
    |- tsconfig.json
|- shared
    |- xxx.ts
    |- ...
```

`frontend` & `backend` are 2 typescript project, with some shared code put into share folder.
Both `frontend` and `backend` have their own typings folder.
There is no `tsconfig.json` in shared folder.

**Problem**
1. When I open file in shared folder, it always throw some error.
Some is because there is no `tsconfig.json` in `shared`, some is because `shared` cannot find proper `typings` (they are in frontend and backend).

2. Compile frontend and backend will be successful
3. This problem may be because vscode regard `shared` as a individual project, and will find its `tsconfig.json` and `typings` seperately.

**Suggestion**
1. Support mark a folder as `shared folder`, do not show error in that folder.
2. Error in that folder should be threw by frontend/backend watch task.
3. Support run multiple tasks parallelly (so that can run frontend/backend watch task at the same time)
4. Or maybe give a option that only use tsserver to show auto-complete hint , but not show error in error panel.

data.title: Prevent http images and untrusted SVGs in browsable extension information
data.body:
Implement new rules for extensions that makes it safer for users to browse the extension marketplace:

- the icon provided in `package.json` may not be a SVG
- the badges provided in the `package.json` may not be SVGs if they are not from trusted badge providers
- image urls in `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md` need to resolve to `https` urls
- images in `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md` may not be SVGs if they are not from trusted badge providers
- urls with the following prefixes identify trusted badge providers
   - `https://api.travis-ci.org/`
   - `https://badge.fury.io/`
   - `https://badges.frapsoft.com/`
   - `https://badges.gitter.im/`
   - `https://badges.greenkeeper.io/`
   - `https://cdn.travis-ci.org/`
   - `https://ci.appveyor.com/`
   - `https://codeclimate.com/`
   - `https://coveralls.io/`
   - `https://david-dm.org/`
   - `https://gemnasium.com/`
   - `https://img.shields.io/`
   - `https://isitmaintained.com/`
   - `https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/`
   - `https://snyk.io/`
   - `https://travis-ci.com/`
   - `https://travis-ci.org/`
   - `https://vsmarketplacebadge.apphb.com/`
   - `https://www.bithound.io/`

- show linting errors on an extension's `package.json`, `README.md` and `CHANGELOG.md` files if they are not adhering  to the constraints above
- the `vsce` command line should perform compliance checks and prevent the upload of extensions if they are not adhering to the constraints above

data.title: ${command:PickProcess} not found after set "protocol":"inspector" in launch.json
data.body:
I'm trying to attach vscode to node process, using default configuration from "Add Configuration" command 

> {
			"type": "node",
			"request": "attach",
			"name": "Attach to Process",
			"processId": "${command:PickProcess}",
			"port": 5858
		}

Running this allow me to pick process but I cannot attach process node show that I need to connect to port 9229 

> Debugger listening on ws://127.0.0.1:9229/4887a797-9bf5-49ae-b808-3c929ea8ef82

and VScode show this error

> Cannot connect to runtime via 'legacy' protocol; consider using 'inspector' protocol (timeout after 10000 ms).

Then I try to change add "protocol":"inspector", to my launch.json

> {
			"type": "node",
			"request": "attach",
			"name": "Attach to Process",
			"processId": "${command:PickProcess}",
			"protocol": "inspector",
			"port": 5858
		}

And then I got this error instead (regardless of port selected 5858 or 9229)

> Please set up the launch configuration file for your application. command 'PickProcess' not found

Removing "processId" will result in debugger attach to first running node process but I need to be able to select other node process.

I'm using VSCode 1.13.1

data.title: Linux: Tasks not using $PATH from ~/.bashrc
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-24-generic

---

I have a custom location for my global npm modules `~/.npm-global`, and I have the bin location set in my `.bashrc` like so ([from npm doc](https://docs.npmjs.com/getting-started/fixing-npm-permissions#option-2-change-npms-default-directory-to-another-directory)):

```
export PATH="/home/ryan/.npm-global/bin:$PATH"
```

When executing `which node-sass` in the vscode terminal I get `/home/ryan/.npm-global/bin/node-sass` which is correct, but when I attempt to run from my `.vscode/tasks.json` file I get an error:

>/bin/bash: node-sass: command not found

The is the task file I am using:

```json
{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "showOutput": "always",
  "isBackground": true,
  "echoCommand": true,
  "tasks": [
    {
      "taskName": "Build Client Sass",
      "command": "node-sass",
      "args": [
        "-w",
        "./src/client/sass/main.scss",
        "./dist/client/assets/css/media-server.min.css",
        "--output-style",
        "compressed"
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

Once I change `"command": "node-sass"` to `"command": "/home/ryan/.npm-global/bin/node-sass"` then it works.

Basically, I don't think that the tasks are loading the `$PATH` information correctly...

data.title: F5 debug fails when directory path contains "_" (underscore)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these -->
- VSCode Version:  1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Create a directory structure like c:\users\myusername\documents\\_prj\MyNTierSystem\AngularApp
2.  Open the folder AngularApp
3.  Hit f5 to launch the app.  
4. Error at the top looks like this -- there is no backslash before the directory name that begins with an underscore:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25128410/27519192-f043a89e-59ab-11e7-8a23-e2abce644a83.png)

5. Exit Visual Studio Code and rename the _prj director to just prj.
6. Open folder AngularApp
7. Hit f5 to start debugging
8. Debugging starts correctly.

data.title: Provide easier keybinding for "Command Palette"/"Show All Commands"
data.body: "Command Palette" or "Show All Commands" should have a very easy to press keybinding like <kbd>Ctrl</kbd><kbd>Ctrl</kbd> or <kbd>Shift</kbd><kbd>Shift</kbd> (double press), IMHO. Then users will be expected to using this frequently for exploring all available commands(and features), which is a good way to explore many features which are not very noticeable.

data.title: [Feature] Allow to invoke search/find in files widget with query prefilled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (779a7dfa682e31d870680caea572a11d009ab447, 2017-06-23T05:59:57.891Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: none
---

As a extension developer I'd like to be able to open search/findInFiles action with prefilled search query as an argument.

My use case scenario - I have a [TreeView](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/tree-view-sample) widget with a list of items presented.
Whenever user clicks on the non-collapsible item, I'd like them to perform a quick search/findInFiles action in the workspace.

```javascript
public getTreeItem(element: Item): TreeItem {
    return {
        label: element.name,
        collapsibleState: element.isGroup ? TreeItemCollapsibleState.Collapsed : TreeItemCollapsibleState.None,
        command: element.isGroup ? void 0 : {
            command: 'openhab.command.findInFiles', // <- my custom command
            arguments: [element.name],
            title: 'Find references'
        }
     ...
   }
}
```

And in `activate()`:

```js
    context.subscriptions.push(commands.registerCommand('openhab.command.findInFiles', (query) => {
        commands.executeCommand('workbench.action.findInFiles', query)
    }));
```

### Expected result
Search sidebar opens with input field prefilled with `query` string and search action is performed right away.

### Actual result
My Search sidebar opens, but my query is not passed to the input field.
Also, `Ctrl + Shift + F` doesn't perform the search right away - user needs to hit `Enter` key first.

data.body:

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new project with `yarn init`
2. Run `yarn install electron`
3. Create new .ts file and try to import electron module and get suggestions about exported modules via `import {} from 'electron`

https://github.com/electron/electron-typescript-definitions/issues/65

data.title: Suggestion: Allow 'local' color theme changes
data.body:
I often have multiple projects open in multiple instances of VSCode.  Using different color themes on each open instance is a very useful way to provide a visual clue as to which context (project) I'm in. At the moment VSCode will change the color theme simultaneously on all open instances whenever it is changed in one.  It would be desirable if there was a 'temporarily change scheme for just this instance' command that didn't affect other instances.
